docs.lead_paragraph: Under the new health care proposal from Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana, a drug industry offer to help Medicare patients save money could end up costing the Medicare program itself a lot more money. In June, the drug industry reached a big cost-savings deal with Mr. Baucus and the White House, meant to reduce the nation's drug bill by $80 billion over 10 years. One way was to give Medicare patients a 50 percent discount on the price of brand-name drugs during the period each year when many patients find themselves in a coverage gap known as the doughnut hole.
docs.abstract: Congressional Budget Office calculates that Sen Max Baucus's new health care proposal could cost Medicare program more money by not covering patients who currently have 50 percent discount on price of brand-name drugs during coverage gaps (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: A new study tries to calculate the human cost of tens of millions of Americans' doing without health insurance. Researchers from Harvard Medical School say lack of insurance can be linked to about 45,000 deaths a year in the United States, a toll greater than the number of people who die annually of kidney disease.
docs.abstract: Harvard Medical School study finds lack of health insurance can be linked to about 45,000 deaths annually in US; results of study are posted online and will be published in December issue of The American Journal of Public Health; photo (S)
docs.snippet: A new study tries to calculate the human cost of tens of millions of Americans' doing without health insurance.      Researchers from Harvard Medical School say lack of insurance can be linked to about 45,000 deaths a year in the United States,  a...

docs.lead_paragraph: The White House on Thursday took the first steps toward addressing a problem that many doctors say is driving up health care costs: exorbitant malpractice claims and sky-high premiums for liability insurance. President Obama directed Kathleen Sebelius, right, secretary of health and human services, to announce within 30 days that the department would begin accepting proposals from states, localities and various health organizations for demonstration projects devised to improve patient safety and doctor-patient communication; ensure timely payments to injured patients; and reduce insurance liability premiums for providers. The projects are a concession to Republicans by the president, who has said he does not perceive medical malpractice to be a big factor in the cost of health care and does not think liability awards should be capped.
docs.abstract: Pres Obama directs Health and Human Services Secretary Kathleen Sebelius to announce initiative within 30 days; department will begin accepting proposals from states, localities and various health organizations for projects aimed at improving patient safety and doctor-patient communication, ensure timely payments to injured patients and reduce insurance liability premiums for providers; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Democrats are anxiously watching Massachusetts, where state lawmakers are considering whether to allow Gov. Deval Patrick to appoint an interim successor to the seat left vacant by the death of Senator Edward M. Kennedy.

headline.main: Watching Massachusetts, for More Than One Reason

docs.abstract: The insurance exchange in Massachusetts may offer a glimpse of other state exchanges in the future.
docs.snippet: The insurance exchange in Massachusetts may offer a glimpse of other state exchanges in the future.

docs.lead_paragraph: As the White House and Congress continue debating how best to provide coverage to tens of millions of Americans currently without health insurance, a new study (PDF) is meant to offer a stark reminder of why lawmakers should continue to try. Researchers from Harvard Medical School say the lack of coverage can be tied to about 45,000 deaths a year in the United States - a toll that is greater than the number of people who die each year from kidney disease.

headline.main: Harvard Medical Study Links Lack of Insurance to 45,000 U.S. Deaths a Year

docs.abstract: A study by researchers from Harvard Medical School says the lack of insurance coverage can be tied to about 45,000 deaths a year in the United States.
docs.snippet: A study by researchers from Harvard Medical School says the lack of insurance coverage can be tied to about 45,000 deaths a year in the United States.

docs.lead_paragraph: The White House took the first steps on Thursday toward setting up demonstration projects intended to explore solutions to a problem that many doctors say is driving up health care costs: exorbitant malpractice claims and sky-high premiums for liability insurance.

headline.main: Updated: White House Ponders Malpractice Liability

docs.abstract: The administration moves cautiously on an explosive issue: tort reform.
docs.snippet: The administration moves cautiously on an explosive issue: tort reform.

docs.lead_paragraph: COLLEGE PARK, Md. - President Obama implored Americans on Thursday to "take the high road" in the effort to pass health care legislation, saying that the battle will be remembered as one of the defining moments in the nation's history.

headline.main: Obama Calls Health Care Fight a 'Defining Moment'

docs.abstract: At a rally in Maryland, the president continues to call for a public insurance option, even though such a provision isn't included in the latest bill.
docs.snippet: At a rally in Maryland, the president continues to call for a public insurance option, even though such a provision isn't included in the latest bill.
